scenes.background: You are leading a project team that has just received an urgent assignment requiring a significant amount of work to be completed within a tight deadline. The team is feeling a lot of pressure, and morale is low, with some members showing signs of frustration and anxiety. One of the team members, Alex, says, 'This is impossible! We can't get this done in time.' You responded by suggesting breaking the tasks into smaller parts. The team seemed somewhat relieved but still on edge. [Monica] and [Bob] exchange concerned looks. Monica then speaks up, 'Even with smaller tasks, the deadline is still too tight.' Bob, looking frustrated, adds, 'I don't think anyone here believes we can actually pull this off.' You then acknowledged the team's feelings and opened the floor for discussion. Now, Monica sighs and says, 'Even if we discuss our concerns, the time isn't going to magically expand.' Bob, rubbing his temples, mutters, 'This is just going to be a disaster waiting to happen.' You then opened the floor for suggestions but also pushed the team to continue working. Bob, feeling the pressure, stands up and paces around the room, and Monica crosses her arms tightly. You tried to encourage the team to stay positive. Monica, still skeptical, leans against the wall and says, 'How do we stay positive when the odds are stacked against us?'
scenes.description: Bob, looking defeated, sits back down and says, 'Maybe we should just accept that we're going to fail.'

options.text: I understand how you feel, Bob. But let's focus on what we can do right now. Every little bit counts.
options.analysis: You acknowledged Bob's feelings and encouraged the team to focus on actionable steps, showing high emotional perception and empathy.

options.text: I get that it's tough, but giving up isn't an option. We need to push through and give it our best shot.
options.analysis: You encouraged the team to stay determined and focused, showing good self-regulation and motivational skills.

options.text: If accepting failure is your idea of contributing, Bob, maybe we should just get back to work and try our best.
options.analysis: You addressed Bob's defeatist attitude directly and pushed the team to continue working, showing moderate emotional perception and self-regulation.
